verses.verse: (Mt 5.28) “I have made a covenant with my eyes; how, then, could I look upon a virgin?
What would be my portion from God above and my heritage from the Almighty (Traditional rendering of Heb Shaddai) on high?
Does not calamity befall the unrighteous and disaster the workers of iniquity?
(2 Chr 16.9; Prov 5.21) Does he not see my ways and number all my steps?
(Mic 2.11) “If I have walked with falsehood, and my foot has hurried to deceit—
(Job 6.2, 3; 27.5, 6) let me be weighed in a just balance, and let God know my integrity!—
(Job 23.11) if my step has turned aside from the way, and my heart has followed my eyes, and if any spot has clung to my hands,
(Lev 26.16) then let me sow and another eat, and let what grows for me be rooted out.
(Job 24.15) “If my heart has been enticed by a woman and I have lain in wait at my neighbor’s door,
(Jer 8.10) then let my wife grind for another, and let other men kneel over her.
(Gen 38.24; Deut 22.22-24) For that would be a heinous crime; that would be a criminal offense;
(Job 15.30; 20.28; 26.6) for that would be a fire consuming down to Abaddon, and it would burn to the root all my harvest.
(Deut 24.14, 15) “If I have rejected the cause of my male or female slaves, when they brought a complaint against me,
what then shall I do when God rises up? When he makes inquiry, what shall I answer him?
(Mal 2.10) Did not he who made me in the womb make them? And did not one fashion us in the womb?
(Job 20.19; 22.7, 9) “If I have withheld anything that the poor desired or have caused the eyes of the widow to fail
(Job 22.7; 29.12) or have eaten my morsel alone and the orphan has not eaten from it—
for from my youth I reared the orphan (Heb him) like a father, and from my mother’s womb I guided the widow (Heb her) —
if I have seen anyone perish for lack of clothing or a poor person without covering,
(Deut 31.20) whose loins have not blessed me, and who was not warmed with the fleece of my sheep;
(Job 22.9) if I have raised my hand against the orphan because I saw I had supporters at the gate;
(Job 38.15) then let my shoulder blade fall from my shoulder, and let my arm be broken from its socket.
(v 3|JOB 31:3; Job 13.11) For I was in terror of calamity from God, and I could not have faced his majesty.
(Mk 10.24) “If I have made gold my trust or called fine gold my confidence,
(Ps 62.10) if I have rejoiced because my wealth was great or because my hand had gotten much,
(Deut 4.19; Ezek 8.16) if I have looked at the sun (Heb the light) when it shone or the moon moving in splendor,
and my heart has been secretly enticed, and my mouth has kissed my hand,
(v 11) this also would be an iniquity to be punished by the judges, for I should have been false to God above.
(Prov 17.5) “If I have rejoiced at the ruin of those who hated me or exulted when evil overtook them—
(Mt 5.44) I have not let my mouth sin by asking for their lives with a curse—
(Job 22.7) if those of my tent ever said, ‘O that we might be sated with his flesh!’ (Meaning of Heb uncertain) —
(Gen 19.2, 3; Rom 12.13) the stranger has not lodged in the street; I have opened my doors to the traveler—
(Gen 3.8; Prov 28.13) if I have concealed my transgressions as others do, (Or as Adam did) by hiding my iniquity in my bosom,
(Ex 23.2) because I stood in great fear of the multitude, and the contempt of families terrified me, so that I kept silence and did not go out of doors—

(Job 19.7; 30.20, 24, 28; 35.14) O that I had one to hear me! (Here is my signature! Let the Almighty (Traditional rendering of Heb Shaddai) answer me!) O that I had the indictment written by my adversary!
Surely I would carry it on my shoulder; I would bind it on me like a crown;
(v 4|JOB 31:4; Job 1.3; 29.25) I would give him an account of all my steps; like a prince I would approach him.
(Gen 4.10, 11) “If my land has cried out against me and its furrows have wept together,
(Lev 19.13; 1 Kings 21.19; Jas 5.4) if I have eaten its yield without payment and caused the death of its owners,
(Gen 3.18) let thorns grow instead of wheat and foul weeds instead of barley.” The words of Job are ended.
